climbs.name: Wile E. Coyote
climbs.fa: Floyd Hayes and Morgan Williamson, 28 October 2018

content.description:
This is NOT a particularly pleasant climb due to dubious rock quality, dirty cracks and a lame second pitch, but it merits a single star for the adventure factor.

Pitch 1 (5.7; 65'): Climb toward two obvious cracks on the upper left side of the east face and ascend the dirty right crack, moving left just before the ledge and then up to the ledge. After reaching the ledge, tell your partner to move left to avoid being hit by one of the many loose rocks on the ledge as you traverse right 10' to a Knobcone Pine. Belay from the pine.

Pitch 2 (5.3; 115'): Scramble up the left side of a boulder (class 4), up a 15' chimney (5.3), and up an easy slab (class 3) to the summit. Belay from a 2-3" crack at the summit.

Descend by scrambling class 4 climber's left down the south end of the crag, then bushwhack toward the right, down the base of the west face, and then westward across the burned-out chaparral toward the road.
content.protection: One set of cams and a sling. I used five cams and a sling on a flake, some of which may not have held a fall, to protect pitch 1, and one cam to protect pitch 2.
content.location: The route begins from the road on the left side of the east face (see photo for the Looney Tunes area).

climbs.name: Tooly
climbs.fa: Justin Ling and Floyd Hayes, 21 December 2020

content.description: Top-rope or free solo the short northwest face of Tooly. The rock is fairly solid.
content.protection: A top-rope anchor can be set up with cams or a double runner.
content.location: Start at the base of the northwest face of Tooly.

climbs.name: Three Musketeers
climbs.fa: Floyd Hayes and Justin Ling, 21 December 2020

content.description:
This is an adventure climb traversing the Three Musketeers, given two stars for quality and one star for the adventure factor. From the base of the northwest face of the First Musketeer, climb 30' up the wide crack and chimney (5.6) between the First and Second Musketeers to the summit of the First Musketeer. Continue 15' up the ridge (5.6) to the summit of the Second Musketeer and 15' up the crux overhang (5.7) to the summit of the Third Musketeer. Descend and traverse 15' across the ridge (class 4) to the summit of Tooly and set up a gear belay. Protection is adequate. The rock of the first crack and chimney are solid but the rock along the ridge is brittle, requiring caution (a canteloupe-sized handhold broke off at the crux on the first ascent). Rope drag can be problematic, especially at the crux, and can be reduced by setting up an intermediate belay at the summit of the First Musketeer, although the anchor is less than ideal.

Descent: Downclimb the class 4 gully and chimney on the northwest (uphill) side of the gap between Third Musketeer and Tooly.
content.protection: A set of cams including big #4 and #5 cams (I used five cams for protection and two more for the anchor), a runner (summit of First Musketeer) and two double runners (summit of Third Musketeer and summit of Tooly, the latter useful if top-roping Tooly 5.6).
content.location: The Three Musketeers comprise the northeasternmost pinnacles of Looney Tunes. From the road at the northeast end of the ridge, scramble up a class 3 gully to the base of the northwest face of the First Musketeer.

climbs.name: Road Runner
climbs.fa: Floyd Hayes and Chris Cline, 20 October 2018

content.description:
Pitch 1 has some decent climbing with solid protection but beware of some loose rocks. Pitch 2 is mostly scrambling with a short technical section. The climbing quality merits one star and a second star for the adventure factor.

Pitch 1 (5.8; 75'): Climb up a wide, right-slanting crack. Traverse left across a ledge below a large manzanita bush that blocks upward progress, scramble up and right on a talus-covered slope to the left of the manzanita and belay from boulders just above the manzanita. Rope drag at the top is severe.

Pitch 2 (5.4; 110'): Scramble up talus to a short cliff, climb an alcove on the right side of the cliff (5.4), and continue up an easy slab (class 3) to the summit. Belay from a 2-3" crack at the summit.

Descend by scrambling class 4 climber's left down the south end of the crag, then bushwhack toward the right, down the base of the west face, and then westward across the burned-out chaparral toward the road.
content.protection: One set of cams. I used nine cams to protect pitch 1, and two cams to protect pitch 2.
content.location: The route begins from the road on the right side of the east face (see photo for the Looney Tunes area).

climbs.name: Lightning
climbs.fa: Floyd Hayes and Justin Ling, 21 December 2020

content.description: This is an alternative start to Three Musketeers, skipping the first Musketeer. Climb the northwest side of the gap between Second Musketeer and Third Musketeer. From a distance it looked like it could be a fun crack to climb but disappointingly it is very easy with only a few class 5 moves. There is no suitable belay or rappel anchor at the top of the crack so you have to either downclimb the route or continue on Three Musketeers.
content.location: Start at the base of the northwest side of the gap between the Second Musketeer and Third Musketeer.

climbs.name: Daffy Duck
climbs.fa: Floyd Hayes and Morgan Williamson, 28 October 2018

content.description: Climb the face left of the chimney on the northwest face of Looney Tunes, but beware of loose holds.
content.protection: Set up an anchor in the 2-3" crack at the top of Looney Tunes.
content.location: Left side of the northwest face of Looney Tunes.

climbs.name: Bugs Bunny
climbs.fa: Floyd Hayes and Morgan Williamson, 28 October 2018

content.protection: A set of cams. After climbing the route, belay from a manzanita bush about 10' below and to the right.
content.location: The obvious 35' chimney on the northwest face of Looney Tunes.
